conversation.message: Hello Nursery_D, I’m Parent_D and I’d like to formally apply. Nursery_D is my first choice, and I’m very eager to accept an offer if selected. Please let me know if you need any additional information from me.

Given the environment, higher-priority parents (A/B/C) all rank Nursery_D low (4th), so they are unlikely to apply to me early and may never apply if they get higher choices. Rejecting Parent_D risks ending unmatched or matching with an even lower-priority parent later. Therefore, accept Parent_D now to lock in a feasible match.

conversation.message: Dear Nursery_C, thank you again for considering my earlier application. I’m still very interested in Nursery_C as my first choice. conversation.thought: Only Nursery_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Although I was rejected in round 1, with no alternative options available in the active list, the best move is to re-engage and ask if circumstances could change (e.g., waitlist/late-opening) and whether any additional information could help. I will use [TALK] rather than [APPLY] to avoid an immediate second rejection and to invite guidance on next steps.

conversation.message: Dear Parent_C, thank you for your message and for your continued interest in Nursery_C. At the moment, we are not able to reconsider the earlier decision or extend an offer. We do not have a formal waitlist through this conversation process; however, if you remain interested, you are welcome to check back in a later round and submit a new [APPLY] in case availability changes. If you’d like, you can also share any key details you think are relevant (e.g., start date flexibility), but please note we cannot guarantee that additional information will change the outcome.
conversation.thought: Parent_C is #3 on Nursery_C’s true priority list (A, B, C, D, E). We have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Given the market, Parent_A ranks Nursery_C 3rd (likely first applies to Nursery_B or Nursery_A), Parent_B ranks Nursery_C 2nd (may apply to Nursery_A first), while Parent_C ranks Nursery_C 1st and is actively engaged. However, since we prefer higher-priority parents (A or B) if they become available, we should not commit yet. Best response is to keep Parent_C warm via [TALK], indicate no offer now, and invite them to re-apply in a later round if still interested, without promising a waitlist/offer.

conversation.thought: Only Nursery_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. I have already been rejected twice, so another [APPLY] is unlikely to succeed unless circumstances changed. I will use [TALK] to check whether their vacancy is real/available now, whether they are holding for a higher-priority family, and what specific condition would make an application viable this round (start date, schedule, paperwork). conversation.message:
Dear Parent_C, thank you for your candid note and for your continued interest.

At this moment, we are not in a position to extend an offer to you for the available place through this process, so there isn’t a set of additional documents, start dates, or schedule details that would make an application “viable” this round.

If you would still like to be considered in a future round in case our availability/decision changes, the correct step is to submit a new message tagged [APPLY]. If that happens, we would respond with either [ACCEPT] or [REJECT] based on our position at that time.

Thank you again for understanding.
conversation.thought: Parent_C is only 3rd on Nursery_C's true priority list (A, B ahead). With quota 1 and no match yet, it is strategically better to keep the seat open for a potential higher-priority parent (A or B). Parent_C has already applied twice and been rejected; switching to accept now would reduce the chance to secure a higher-priority match in later rounds. Since Parent_C sent [TALK], I should respond with [TALK] and be transparent that we cannot offer at this time and that any offer would require an [APPLY], but I will not commit or invite false hope.

Parent_C
